name: Arelith Arcane Archer Concept (No Longer Zen)
author: Yithare

posts.author: Yithare
posts.content:
Hello All! I used to play NWN on an old PW server waaaaay back in the day, so you can imagine my excitement at the release of the EE. However, my old server is not currently up and I've decided to bide the time by playing on Arelith and with a concept I've never tried...A ranged character! *Le Gasp*. The idea I have is for either a Ranger/Monk/AA or Ranger/Cleric/AA. As the title states I want to make it a Zen Archer, and I am taking the Sniper path for the ranger with wood elf as my subrace. I want to have a build that can hold well in PvP but to be focused more towards PvM. My big questions are how does the Ranger/Cleric/AA compare to the Ranger/Monk/AA? What is your recommendations for level progression/starting stats/ feats/ skills? What's the max dps for each build? What does the AC look like for each build? How much does AC matter in Arelith? (I ask that last question because I've heard some crazy stories of monsters chewing through characters with an AC above 40 O.O ) The only thing I really know as far as the difference is that going the cleric route has more damage potential whereas going the monk route has more survivability (at least I think).

Thank you in advance from this new Arelith player! I look forward to playing with you :)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi there, Yithare, and welcome. You might have to be a bit patient here - Arelith ain't the natural hunting ground, so the stuff on the PW sub-forum probably needs looking at before the great and good can offer you a build (I'm not including myself in that, by the way). Lots of rule changes (and of course the level 30 max) - including, it seems, not needing a caster class level in order to take AA. That could change things a lot.

Good to meet you, anyway!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Having had a look at the Arelith stuff, I'm not sure why you want Ranger - I know it's a full AB class, but still, a Rogue, Wizard, AA build might still work better for you. Is there something in particular that Ranger brings that I've missed (which is entirely possible)?

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: Having had a look at the Arelith stuff, I'm not sure why you want Ranger - I know it's a full AB class, but still, a Rogue, Wizard, AA build might still work better for you. Is there something in particular that Ranger brings that I've missed (which is entirely possible)?
The thing is that on Arelith Rangers qualify for AA, just like arcane casters do. You can also choose different "paths" for the Ranger. The sniper path gives the Ranger archery related class feats rather than dual wield feats. Rangers also get bonus damage with increasing levels, so they are in fact strong candidates for AA builds there.

I would not bother with Cleric or Zen for such a build. I would go the normal dexterity route and take a tumble class for third class. 5 levels of SD for HIPS is great for survival. I know that Rangers get HIPS in outdoors areas, but that limits it a bit and it comes late, so that does not leave much room for AA and a tumble class.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Cheers, Mick - education is never wasted! So, with a dexer, an AA/Ranger is fine. As is normally the case with me, rather than chucking 5 levels into SD, would a Monk be a good Tumble-class idea? Speedy, snipey  and stealthy. The only real potential issue is about the level 30 cap - given you'll need a minimum of 3 Ranger and 3 Monk - or is it 4 of one of them to hit the BAB for access to AA - which I believe is still 6? And then you're a bit tied in to AA if you really want to crunch it. Anyhoo, over to the people who know what they're doing...

Yes! That is exactly why I chose a Ranger. I get all of those awesome feats out the gate, and that frees up feats I can get later. The big reason I wanted Zen is because I wanted high wisdom so I can either multiclass into Monk (Which gives me speed, and Wis AC bonus ((It's also got tumble ;) )) So the high Wis contributes to the AC, and if I keep it higher than Dex I can have a solid AB)), or the other hand, I was considering Cleric for the healing and buffs (High Wis equals extra spell slots as well), which could significantly increase my damage, but I would be sacrificing good AC and speed. However, with Cleric comes the possibility of Improved Invisibility, in which case I may not need HIPS. I was thinking at least 6 lvls Ranger so I can get my animal companion as well as some spell casting (High Wis will give me bonus slots) then go Monk at 7th level and continue monk til either 9th or 10th level (If to 9th switch back to Ranger at 10th) Then take AA at 11th level when I have the AB to reach it. Of course I'd carry on as AA till atleast lvl 20 or 21 (+5 vs. +6 arrows), but after that point I'm kinda stumped haha. And with Cleric I have no idea really how I would split levels. I just know that I would want great damage buffs and either extend or max spell at some point lol.

EDIT: And as far as the SD, though that sounds pretty good, you need a tumble of 5 to even become a SD....which means that I would need to take a tumble class other than SD first. So unfortunately I don't think SD is a viable option for an AA build with Ranger

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: Some of the AA special abilities rely on DEX, not WIS, even with Zen Archery. If you choose Ranger / Monk / AA, go for high DEX and 14 WIS to be able to cast Ranger spells. Remember though, you have to have no armor, not even light armor, or you don't get the Monk armor bonus.

posts.author: Yithare
posts.content:
So how's this: At creation I start with 16 Dex, 14Str, 14 Wis, 12 Con, 12 Int, 8 Char. I take the gift of Grace (+2 to Dex for 18) and either take Gift of Insight (+2 WIs for 16) or Gift of Endurance (+2 to Con to give me 14). Take the wood elf subrace and path of the sniper for archery feats. Go Ranger lvl 6, and at 7th level go Monk until lvl 9 (which is 3 lvls monk) then go back to Ranger at lvl 10, or just stick with monk til lvl 10 (which makes 4 lvls monk) and take my first AA lvl at 11th lvl. 

Now, another thing I've been considering...what if my total lvl split looks like 8 Ranger/ 5 Monk/ 17 AA? By then I'll be able to cast second lvl Ranger spells (due to bonus spell slots from Wis) which gives me access to Cat's Grace as well as One With The Land, and Protection from Elements. I'll have Purity of Body from Monk class, which gives me immunity to non-magical disease and a huge boon to saves overall. And at 17th lvl AA I get +9 arrows. Does that sound formidable? I could switch out one lvl of monk for another AA lvl to make the split look like Ranger 8/ Monk 4/ AA 18 which would give me 2 bonus feats from epic AA lvls and increase my imbue arrow from 13d6 to 14d6. Though I would lose the disease immunity, I still keep the +4 to all saves with monk. Thoughts? 

EDIT: Although if I waited til lvl 13 to take AA, I would have access to my 2nd lvl Ranger spells earlier and knock out my split for ranger and monk lvls then just lock into AA for the rest of my progression...?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content:
I would wait until level 27 to take the last level of Monk for a skill dump in Tumble and Discipline. Also, I would go for that AA 18 bonus feat.

How about 14 STR, 18 DEX, 12 CON, 12 WIS, 10 INT, and 8 CHA? Since you only get level 2 Ranger spells, you don't need more WIS, except maybe for AC. Take the gifts as you already described, +2 DEX and either +2 CON or +2 WIS.

posts.author: Yithare
posts.content:
Ok, here's what I got so far:

Warden of the Greyhunt (Arelith)
•The Wardens of the Greyhunt are faithful servants of nature and defenders of the wood. These warriors are renowned for their skills with a bow, and their swift retribution. Their name strikes fear into the hearts of nature’s enemies, their eyes ever shifting through the foliage searching for these silent stalkers. Wardens, however, know that their arrows are meant to be felt…not seen. Their ability to engage an enemy from a distance, and disengage with blinding speed dazes and confuses their prey. They even use their bows in melee combat, dodging and weaving past enemy attacks and loosing an arrow when their opponent’s guard is open. Their only moral obligation is to their order, their people, their own personal code, and to the balance of nature.  Should you threaten any of the things they stand for…you’d best watch your back….else one of their arrows may find you, whistling through the dark. This is my mid-epic lvl 30 Arcane Archer build for Arelith.

•Ranger (8), Monk (4), Arcane Archer (18)
•Alignment: Lawful Neutral 
•Ranger Path: Path of the Sniper (trade Dual Wield feats for Point Blank Shot and Rapid Shot at 1st lvl)
•Race: Wood Elf (+2 Str, -2 Dex, WF: Longbow ((This subrace keeps the -2 to Con at creation when selecting Elf)
•Gifts: Gift of Grace (+2 Dex), Gift of Insight (+2 Wis), Gift of the Sneak (+4 Hide, +4 MS)
Starting stats at creation screen (Before Sub-race selection and gifts): Str 12, Dex 18, Con 12, Int 12, Wis 14, Cha 8. Starting Stats after subrace selection: Str 14, Dex 16, Con 12, Int 12, Wis 14, Cha 8. Starting stats after gifts: Str 14, Dex 18, Con 12, Int 12, Wis 16, Cha 8. Dump all increases into Dex.

•01: Ranger(1): Luck of Heroes, Favored Enemy I: Up to You (And feats gained from Sniper Path/ Wood Elf)
•02: Ranger(2)
•03: Ranger(3): Blind Fight
•04: Ranger(4): DEX +1 (Dex=19)
•05: Ranger(5): Favored Enemy II: Up to You
•06: Ranger(6): Animal Companion (I’m picking Bear, but to each their own), Dodge
•07: Monk(1)
•08: Monk(2): DEX +1 (Dex=20)
•09: Monk(3): Mobility
•10: Ranger(7)
•11: Ranger(8)
•12: AA(1): DEX+1 (Dex=21) Improved Critical: Longbow
•13: AA(2): Imbue Arrow received
•14: AA(3)
•15: AA(4): Called Shot, Seeker Arrow I received
•16: AA(5): DEX +1 (Dex=22)
•17: AA(6): Seeker Arrow II received
•18: AA(7): Skill Focus: Tumble
•19: AA(8): Hail of Arrows received
•20: AA(9): DEX+1 (Dex=23)
•21: AA(10): Armor Skin, Death Arrow received
•22: AA(11)
•23: AA(12)
•24: AA(13):  DEX+1, Great Dexterity (Dex=25)
•25: AA(14): Great Dexterity II (Dex=26)
•26: AA(15)
•27: Monk(4): Great Dexterity III (Dex=27)
•28: AA(16): DEX+1 (Dex=28)
•29: AA(17)
•30: AA: (18): Epic Prowess, Epic WF: Longbow

•Hitpoints: 286

•Saving Throws (Fortitude/Will/Reflex): 19/23/14 (I think I calculated that right)

I'm not 100 percent sure on how to calculate the BAB or AC to complete accuracy. But both should be decent. I'm also not sure as to how many skill points it'll have in total as I noticed something weird with Arelith. When I hit 3rd level in Arelith I suddenly get an additional 2 skill points even though my Int is only 12. I.e. I started out at lvl 2 with 5 skill points to spend, then when I hit lvl 3 I got 7 skill points to spend. I'm not sure if this is some kind of bug, or if that is just how Arelith works. If that's truely the case. I would  just put my points into Discipline, Hide, Move Silently, Listen, and Spot when taking ranger lvls and save 2 points each level after 2nd. Then when I hit Monk at 7th lvl, dump into Tumble and discipline until I hit Ranger at 10th lvl, then continue with Discipline, Hide, Move Silently, Listen, Spot until I hit AA at 12th lvl. Once I go AA I pour into Hide, Move Silenty, Listen, and Spot and then....save points til 27th? Once I take Monk at 27th dump back into Discipline and Tumble, then at 28th AA continue with Hide, Move Silently, Listen, Spot...I may have a few points left over and the only things I would consider for that is Lore or Heal I think.

Any thoughts thus far?

posts.author: Empyre65
posts.content: It looks good to me. Listen and Spot do almost the same thing, so it is a little bit redundant to put points in both. However, Listen lets you "see" around corners, but not hiding enemies that are standing still, which Spot helps you with, so spending points in both is not completely useless, if you can't find anywhere better to put the skill points.
